messages.subject: Re: [nihontostudy] Interesting nakago shape
messages.msgSnippet: Pete and all, I ve been away for a bit (again), I ll work on catching up with the offline questions. These are cut out for mounting on a koshirae with a spring
messages.messageBody:
Pete and all,
I've been away for a bit (again), I'll work on catching up with the offline questions.

These are cut out for mounting on a koshirae with a spring retention clip. Not only are they seen on recent military mounts, but also on bakumatsu period toppei koshirae. In both cases, the single hanger style of wearing must have presented too many opportunities for the sword to tip out of the saya.

Interestingly, I've also seen this on older guards mounted on earlier koshirae, sometimes in Japanese museum collections. It's not at all clear if these were swapped-in tsuba, or if spring clip retention was also used at an earlier date for some reason. Perhaps for particularly unstable swordsmen.

To show I haven't (just) been sitting on the beach, a few recent hawk photos for some guy that goes in for that sort of thing:

http://www.flickr.com/photo_zoom.gne?id=255912318&size=l
http://www.flickr.com/photo_zoom.gne?id=253671398&size=l
http://www.flickr.com/photo_zoom.gne?id=249338979&size=l
http://www.flickr.com/photo_zoom.gne?id=249387474&size=l

Jim

----- Original Message -----
From: klepet33319
To: nihontostudy@yahoogroups.com
Sent: Friday, October 06, 2006 1:30 PM
Subject: [nihontostudy] Interesting nakago shape


Would anyone have an idea of why this nakagoana had to be shaped this
way? I have two pictures in the Pete Klein photos, one of a tsuba, Ko
Kinko, the other from the Nihonto Koza, Japanese edition, vol. 7, page
180.
Thanks much.

http://ph.groups.yahoo.com/group/nihontostudy/photos/browse/7936?c=
